etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Judy. From crinol- + -ette

definitions: A narrow version of the crinoline, designed to support skirts projecting from behind, and usually composed of half hoops suspended around the back of the legs.

notes.text: The crinolette began to replace the crinoline in the mid 1860s, and was in turn superseded by the bustle.
